anchor.surface_text: The two questions thus refereed to the High Court have been answered by it in the affirmative against the appellant assessee. The appellant has therefore come to this court by special leaves against the decision of the High Court in the two cases referred to it.

A partition under Hindu law can be partial either as to persons or as to properties but the High Court took the view that in fact a complete partition had taken place though after the said partition the appellant and his minor sons again continued as if they were an undivided Hindu family.

concepts.interpretation: Academic Hindu law distinction between partial and complete partition not decisive; factual conduct and findings determine if there was total partition leading to change in business persons

anchor.surface_text: In answering the question against the appellant the High Court has observed that in deciding such a question some important considerations must be borne in mind. Four such considerations have been set out in the judgment of the High Court first, that the mere fact that a new business was started at a time when by such starting there would be a reduction of liability is not by itself proof that it was started with the main object of avoiding the excess profits liability within the meaning of section 10A

concepts.interpretation: Main purpose test requires department to prove avoidance as dominant motive, not incidental; relationship and timing relevant but not conclusive
concepts.unlisted_label: Main Purpose Test under Section 10A EPT Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Multi-factor test for tax avoidance motive

holdings.text: The facts stated in the statement of the case have to be accepted and their correctness is not open to challenge in reference proceedings under section 66(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the facts stated in the statement of the case have to be accepted and their correctness is not open to challenge in reference proceedings under section 66  2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established procedural rule in tax reference proceedings; Tribunal's factual findings binding if supported by evidence.

holdings.text: There was a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8(1) of the Excess Profits Tax Act due to complete partition of the HUF, closure of old family business on January 27, 1942, and commencement of new businesses by groups on January 28, 1942.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts in statement of case show pooling of assets/liabilities, closure of old books, opening new books, s.25A order, representations to ITO indicating general partition and discontinuance; binding on court.

holdings.text: The Hindu undivided family did not continue its existence after January 27, 1942, for purposes of income-tax assessment as old business was closed and new businesses started.

anchor.surface_text: The statement of the case elaborately refers to the conduct of the parties. It points out that so far as the entries in the old family account books are concerned all the assets and liabilities were pooled on January 27, 1942, and divided into two halves...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supported by conduct post-partition, s.25A recognition order, new accounts, and departmental representations; academic Hindu law distinctions not decisive.

holdings.text: The question whether the main purpose in constituting the two firms was avoidance or reduction of liability to excess profits tax under section 10A is primarily a question of fact.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of inquiry into motive is factual; High Court/Tribunal findings not to be interfered with unless unsupported.

holdings.text: There was ample material to justify the Tribunal's finding that the main purpose in constituting the two firms was avoidance or reduction of liability to excess profits tax within section 10A.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Timing, appellant's complete control/finance, treatment as branches, single tax assessment place, book examination support dominant avoidance motive over incidental benefit.
